docs.title: How to Gas Up the Snowblower
docs.text: This guide help you understand how to fill a two cycle snowblower with the correct gas and oil mixture.

docs.title: Background
docs.text: Our snowblower is a two-cycle type that MUST have the proper mixture of oil and gas. This guide shows you how to do this.

docs.title: Gas Container
docs.text: Here is the gas container. Go to the gas station and fill it up. This one holds 1 1/4 gallons of gas. For this guide, we will assume a full container, but you can also use partially filled containers as long as you can estimate the amount of gas in the container.

docs.title: Gas and Oil Mix Calculator
docs.text: Use this MicroSim to calculate how much two-cycle oil to add for a given amount of gas and a target ratio.

docs.title: Gas Cap on the Snowblower
docs.text: This is an image of the gas cap on the snowblower. You will note that it indicates that the proper mixture is 50 to 1.

docs.title: Two Cycle Oil
docs.text: This is a photo of the two cycle oil bottle. Some have a transparent part on the side to show you how much is in the bottle. Ours does not have this.

docs.title: How to Measure the Oil
docs.text: Here I am measuring the oil in the glass beaker and I have about 3.5 ounces. This is just a fraction more than I needed.

docs.title: Label on Gas Can
docs.text: Note the label on the gas can. You should never store pure gas unmixed with oil in this container.

docs.title: About This MicroSim
docs.text: This MicroSim helps learners calculate how much two-cycle oil to add for a given amount of gas and a chosen gas-to-oil ratio. It provides instant feedback in fluid ounces, milliliters, and tablespoons so measurements are easy in the shop or garage.

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
1. Set the Gas (gal) slider to match the amount of gas in your container.
  2. Set the Ratio (gas:oil) slider to match the engine requirement (default is 50:1).
  3. Read the Oil needed values in the display panel and measure that amount of oil.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Understand simple ratios (for example, 50:1)
  • Familiarity with measuring fluids in ounces or milliliters

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
1. Exploration (5 min): Adjust the gas amount from 0.25 to 5 gallons and observe how oil needs change.
  2. Guided Practice (5 min): Set ratio to 50:1 and calculate oil for 1.25 gallons (a common gas can size).
  3. Assessment (5 min): Change the ratio to 40:1 and compute the oil needed for 2.5 gallons.

docs.title: Assessment
docs.text: Students can correctly compute oil amounts for three different gas volumes and ratios.
